content.description:
Sustained climbing up the arete

Far right side of the wall. Walk along the ledge right of Claim Jumper to the far end of the wall. The belay is a bit sketchy.
bolts

climbs.name: The Big Barn Door
climbs.fa: Les McDonald (Free Solo up and down) c.1962

content.description:
The crux comes after the first bolt. It feels a bit exposed getting to this bolt but the arete is really grippy. After you clip the second bolt the climbing gets pretty cruisy so the run out to the anchor doesn't feel too bad. It's a great little route with some fun climbing.

Arriving at the crag it's the route on the right of the huge flake leaning against the wall under the roof.Â 
2 bolts. Anchors at the top with drop in fixed biners for lowering off.

climbs.name: Big Daddy Overhang
climbs.fa: Jim Baldwin, Jim Sinclair, July 1962. FFA: Peter Croft, Tami Knight, 1981

content.description:
Same start as Grand Daddy Overhang on the 5.9 corner, but go straight out the roof, with a bolt at the lip (crux).  More fingercrack above.

huge roof, and out right.
bolts and small gear.

A short route that is great for a rainy day.  I did this on a day when it was pouring rain, but never got wet.

Located about the middle of the wall, in between a bunch of large boulders.  Climbs under the roof to a set of fixed anchors.
Finger to hand size pieces.

Claim Jumper is another Nightmare classic, as are most of the routes there.  
  
 Claim Jumper starts just to the right of Perspective on at a steep slab with a couple of bolts. Ascend to just below a steep crack with a fixed pin. The crux is just after the pin, although getting to the pin is an ordeal in itself. Hope that the pin doesn't pull if you whip on it. After the crux, climb to the left into a thin crack that appears much more difficult than it is and ascend to the shared  anchors of Perspective. 
  
 There are a few ways to climb Claim Jumper. The new McLane guide gives this route .11d....and some of the old guides give it .12b. Depending on your height and how you do it, it could be either, therefore I'll suggest .12a.

Just right of Perspective starting on the smooth, angular feature with two three obvious bolts.
Nothing bigger than Camalot #1. Heavy on small cams and stoppers. Draws for the start.

Zig Zag crack direct start to Morpheus.

Starts on a dirt landing right of the rock slab that goes to the top of Hypertension. Look for the left traversing crack
gear and bolts

Trend right up the easy diagonal crack, but back clean for rope drag. Then follow the the long right facing corner. No hands ledge up high and then power up the left facing corner. You can do a direct start up the bolted corner of It's a Potpourri.

Scramble up the slab that is the top of Hypertension/Presto. Pull up the fixed line to gain the start.
gear

climbs.name: Grand Daddy Overhang
climbs.fa: Dick Culbert, Eric Lance: 1967  FFA : Peter Croft, Tami Knight   1979

content.description:
Start on the 5.9 ramp in the corner under the huge roof, then traverse left via tips underclings.  Anchors at the lip.

under the huge roof.
bolts and small gear.

Fun mixed route that starts on the face between the grand daddy ramp and sentry box. Starts with a couple of boulder problems on bolts, then traverses left on underclings and finishes as for grand daddy ramp. It's not very long, but packs in quite a lot of good movement.

Just look for the chalked-up line following bolts directly underneath the giant roof at nightmare.
4 bolts, a small cam or two for the undercling (red or green c3), a few cams in the range from #0.5-#2 c4 for the finish. Sport Anchors.

A beguiling, I-think-I-can-do-that offwidth that seems to prove most people wrong. 
  
 Start w/ 5.9 hands to fist.  Then a one move transitional pod, and finally about 12' of overhanging, leaning perfect 4.5 Camalot.  Ends with a couple of easy moves and chains.  If you have fat knees, this climb could be pretty tough, though at least they won't be bruised the next day.

The obvious wide crack on the southernmost, lowest section of Nightmare Rock.  This is the first part of NM one encounters on the trail from the road.
Camalots: 1-#2, 2-#3, 1 or 2 #4, 1 #4.5.  A #5 C4 would probably work instead of the 4.5.  A #6 will not fit throughout most, if not all, of the crux.

A long, technical line to the top of the Dream Wall section of Nightmare Rock. It links varied sections of climbing through 6 small roofs, ending in a 5 foot wide slot at the top. The two cruxes at the last two roofs have fixed quick draws, as the clips can be difficult. This route will not succumb to brute force. A technician's delicate problem solving skills are required!Â  Begin in the corner between Morpheus and Who's Your Daddy?Â on a pointy boulder. After 10 feet, pull around the corner to the left, and follow the well bolted line to to very top. 16 bolts

Hard stemming up the bolted corner, gain a ledge. Then look for a bolt on the left bulge, a boulder problem over the bulge and then take the crack up the edge of the arete. Great position.

On top of Presto/Hypertension, look for the bolted corner
bolts and some small cams

Tricky face climbing up the blunt arete. A couple of small pieces fill the void of bolts. Crux pull through the small roof and weave up on wonderful edges.

Behind the big rock at the top of the trail. Look for bolts up the blunt arete
bolts

Begin on Who's Your Daddy. After a few metres of moderate crack climbing at the bottom (single #.5, .75, 1 cam), avoid the normal traverse out to the right on WYD, and climb straight up through the left side of the roof on some 11a moves. The route rejoins WHD for a few metres before the new mid-wall anchor on the left.Â 

For Paternity Test, continue past the mid wall anchor, through one powerful, and one deviously balancy crux to an anchor at the top of the wall. Route grade is up for discussion.Â 


.5, .75. 1 camalot for the bottom, 10 bolts, fixed carabiners on chain anchor.

Perspective is yet another Nightmare classic.Â 

Start in a pumpy overhanging corner and climb through a physical, cruxy bulge above. Continue up to an adequate rest a few meters below the technical crux which is just below a small triangular roof in a little flaring corner. Sustained and aesthetic.

It's possible to top-rope Claim Jumper from the shared anchors with Perspective. You can also reach the anchors of Sentry Box with an exposed traverse out left on a ledge system.

In the past the FFA was attributed to later climbers but an eyewitness account shows that Les McDonald freed it c. 1964!!! Crazy!


Nightmare rock is at Murrin park
Double cams from fingers to hands....one #3 camalot is useful. Stoppers

Presto is the nice bolted line in the small corner just left of Hypertension on the far left side of Nightmare Rock. Easy climbing past three bolts gets you to a good jug rest. From the jug, sustained hard climbing past three more bolts gets you to the anchor. A fun route with cool moves and perfect rock. Climb careful in the beginning as the first bolt rather high up the route.

six bolts

climbs.name: Sentry Box
climbs.fa: Jim Baldwin, Ed Cooper, Oct. 1960. FFA: Eric Weinstein, 1976. Direct: Peter Croft, Tami Knight, 1982

content.description:
The classic hard finger crack at Murrin.  
  
 Ascend a steep 10a crack on the face above some blocks and past an intermediate anchor. Traverse to a stance below a right leaning splitter finger crack on the headwall. A short, but thin and technical crux(12a) lies above. Fight on to the chains. Watch for the rope getting stuck in the crack to the left of the mid-height ledge. 
  
 Do "Sentry Box Direct" for, in my opinion, a better, more sustained version, but beware of the difficult gear placements. There is serious ground fall potential in the first 5m of this variation. 

Nightmare rock is at Murrin Park
singles to #2 Camalot,doubles of yellow and green aliens, stoppers.

Further down the wall from Big Daddy's Ramp, this climbs a short south facing wall.  Start by stepping over a gap, and climb the nice crack in the middle of the face up to the roof and a rap station.  This also stays dry in the rain, I climbed it on a rainy day, but there is some water that seeps at the top.  Not an issue though.

Work around the boulders to the right hand edge of the big roof.
finger to hand size pieces

climbs.name: Who's Your Daddy?
climbs.fa: J. Howe, P. Delaney, G. Ross '02

content.description:
A tricky and technical route, makes for a good warmup when coming to the cliff. Start in the obvious crack to the left of the large flake below the Grandaddy Overhang. Go up the crack, step right when obvious, then up past a bolt to the anchor of Grandaddy Overhang.

Just left of the large flake below the massive overhang.
Pro to 3" ought to do it.

An east facing cliff close to the road (somewhat noisy) that has a good selection of routes 5.10 and above.  Bonus:  many of the pitches will stay dry through the first phases of a Squamish rain siege.
